p: Increasing evidence on the ability of ferutinin to inhibit cell growth and to induce apoptosis both in vitro and in vivo [ 79] has led to a growing of research on ferutinin as an anti-cancer and chemopreventive agent, both alone and in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs [ 84, 85, 86, 87, 88]. In particular, ferutinin had shown pro-apoptotic properties on several cell lines mediated by mitochondrial permeabilization and the release of molecules implicated in intrinsic apoptotic induction and progression. Among them, apoptosis inducing factor (AIF), a mitochondrial oxide-reductase, exerted a relevant role as physiologically participates in the electronic transport and, once it has released from the mitochondrion, moves into the nucleus acting as DNAse [ 89].
